;

;;

;

;Looking at the ancient city of Ani from a distance, there are three obvious buildings from front to back: a mosque, Cathedral, Church of the Savior. ;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;A European-style town in the Islamic world

;

;Kars is the Silk Road A quite alternative city in the western section.

;

;After traveling in Pakistan and Iran for more than a month, I have already become accustomed to the mountains and the Gobi, the minaret and the Grand Bazaar, the call of dawn and dusk with black gauze and white hats, the lively markets and winding alleys... Enter Although the landscape in eastern Turkey changed to gentle slopes and the language changed to Turkic and Kurdish, the strong imprint of Islamic civilization has not weakened at all. But when you come to the northeastern border town of Karls, the cool and elegant cityscape, the streets with a checkerboard structure, the neat and straight stone roads, and even the bank branches shining warmly in the bleak autumn wind make people suddenly feel like they have traveled to a Nordic town.

;

;The unusual origin of Kars comes from: it was occupied by Tsarist Russia for 40 years from 1878, and was planned, built and managed in a European style. of Soviet Russia was ceded to Turkey. Before that, Kars was the capital of the middle Bagratid dynasty. It was successively occupied by the Byzantines, Seljuks, Mongols and Turks in the more than 800 years after the fall of the dynasty. The Bagratid Dynasty was a mini-version established by the only remaining nobles who took advantage of the gap between the Byzantine Empire and the Arab Empire after the once vast Kingdom of Armenia, which controlled hundreds of thousands of people, was divided by the Roman Empire and the Parthian Empire. The Armenian country has been a country for 160 years.

;

;There are no Armenians in Kars today, but just a hundred years ago, 84.1% of the population here was Armenian. Because the Tsarist Russian government was relatively friendly to Armenians, people from Western Armenia (generally referring to the former Armenian territory in Turkey, corresponding to Eastern Armenia, which is now the Republic of Armenia and part of Azerbaijan) who suffered discrimination and abuse from the Ottoman Turkish Empire at that time migrated to Kars , especially during World War I, the Ottoman Turkish Empire implemented a genocidal policy against the Armenians in its territory, resulting in the deaths of 1 million to 1.5 million Armenians. This is known as the Armenian Genocide in history, and even prompted Western Armenians to flee to Kars for refuge. Unfortunately, the good times did not last long. After Soviet Russia ceded Kars to Turkey, the Armenians here had to embark on a journey of survival.

;

;My companions and I found a small hotel to stay in - the hotel sign on Turkey Street is easy to recognize, written as otel, which comes from the French word hotel with a silent h - we were preparing to take advantage of the sun yet. Go down the mountain to see the landmark here, the Seljuk Castle built in the 12th century AD, and Celil, the famous old fox of Kars, comes to visit.

;

;Turkey is a big tourist country, but tourists mainly go to the Aegean coast in the west, the Mediterranean coast in the south and Cappadocia in the center. Even the quiet and elegant Black Sea coast in the north is rarely visited. Not to mention eastern Turkey, which is adjacent to "high-risk areas" such as Syria, Iraq, Iran and the Caucasus. The rare few who make the long journey to Kars are undoubtedly to have a look at the ruins of Ani, and Celil, who has a keen sense of smell, specializes in these people's business. He can track every first-time tourist, and even the backpackers who spend a lot of money can be killed by him before they know the east, west, north, and south. Having said that, the number of tourists here is limited and it cannot support more tourism operators. The tourism transportation in Ani is not developed, so Celil has become an unavoidable broker for tourists.

;

;Celil speaks fluent English, and this skill alone is a talent that can only be encountered within a few hundred miles. He was going to personally take a group to Ani the next day, and he had no control over the two of us. He just wanted to find a car for us and a young man from Melbourne we met on the road to go to Ani, and charged 20 lire per person - I asked about the price for chartered cars, which was 40 lire. The Turkish lira has experienced a 50% plunge in 2018 and a 20% depreciation since the COVID-19 epidemic this year. Now it is only 85 cents in exchange for RMB, but at that time, 1 lira could be exchanged for more than five yuan. This chartered trip was equivalent to three hundred yuan. For the first time, Celil took a third of it - only after we were on the road did we learn that Celil actually asked the simple Melbourne boy for 5 liras more.

;

;Ten years later, another Chinese tourist came to Karls, and he also got three people to charter Celil’s car to Ani. Celil has entered middle age from a young man, and has worked hard to innovate. He originally negotiated a charter price of 100 lire, but after the journey, he charged 50 lire per person. He actually wanted to ask the simple German guy for another 50 lire tip. He was evaluated as "Malicious greed" - I accidentally read this on the Internet and couldn't help laughing.

;

;;

;

;Turkish breakfast in the European-style small town of Karls. ;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;A dynasty growing in the cracks

;

;Early the next morning, sitting In a small restaurant full of locals, I ate a basket of bread with a large bowl of soup made from mutton hamstrings - this is the Turkish version of Runan mutton soup breakfast, and then drove to the ancient capital Ani, 45 kilometers away. This place is located on the Armenian Plateau that connects the Iranian Plateau and the Anatolian Plateau. Along the way is still the typical temperate grassland in Central Asia. The herdsmen are stacking hay into pyramids five or six people high to prepare for the winter.

;

;Ani, the destination of this trip, is the fourth and last capital of the Bagratid dynasty. It was the capital for the longest time, lasting 84 years.

;

;Speaking of the revival of the Bagratid dynasty in Armenia, Robert I, who led Scotland to regain its independence, is comparable to Robert I, who was capricious and devoted to family interests in the movie "Brave Heart". The English invaders betrayed the leader of the rebellion, William Wallace, and then rebelled against the independent Scottish nobleman Robert the Bruce. This man was truly a generational hero known as "Braveheart" in history. Ashote I, the founding monarch of the Bagratid dynasty, was also such a figure. After the fall of the Kingdom of Armenia, the Romans and Persians fought on its territory for many years and were severely weakened. As a result, the newly rising Arabs came from behind and became the conquerors of the Armenian Plateau. In 705 AD, the Arab governor sent by the White-coated Food (Umayyad Dynasty) almost killed all the remaining Armenian nobles, and the Bagratid family survived; more than 40 years later, the White-Coated Food changed dynasties and became the Black-Coated Food (Abbasid Dynasty), sent troops to bloody suppress the uprising launched by the Armenians who took advantage of the chaos, eradicated the local civil resistance forces, and the Bagratid family, who had long been friends with the black-clad Caliphate, once again survived, and they have been together ever since. With its strong support, it became the most powerful political and military force on the Armenian Plateau, and also became a local force that foreign Arab rulers must rely on.

;

;It was at this time that Ashuote I succeeded him as the family governor. On the one hand, the Arab Caliph supported him to neutralize the surrounding separatist forces and became the King of Armenia, hoping to use him to calm down the instability in the Caucasus Mountains so that he could concentrate on dealing with the Byzantine Empire to the west; on the other hand, the Byzantine Emperor Basil I hoped to win over the Armenian nation. They shared the belief in the Kingdom of God, thus forming a siege on the Black Era from the northern flank; on the other hand, Ashot I not only wanted to use the Byzantines to drive away the Arabs, but was also worried that the Byzantine Empire, which believed in Orthodox Christianity, would force the Armenian Apostolic Church to convert. , thereby threatening the legitimacy of his regime. Therefore, Asot I strictly adhered to the principle of keeping a low profile and double-dealing throughout his life. At the same time, he formed alliances with Byzantium and Arabia and watched the two empires fight in front of the Caucasus Mountains. He devoted himself to making Armenia bigger and stronger, and did not let the Arabs He had time to intervene in his own country's affairs and prevented the Byzantines from obtaining practical benefits from the Caucasus.

;

;The first capital of Ashote I after the founding of the country was Bagaran, the base of the Bagratid family. After his son ascended the throne, he moved the capital to Shirakavan. Both places are on the east bank of the Aras River. Today, due to geopolitical changes, the Aras River is the boundary river between Armenia, Turkey, and Iran. More than a thousand years ago, it was the mother river of Armenia. The Bagratid dynasty located its first two capitals on the east bank of the Arras River in order to use the defensive function of the river to keep foreign enemies west of the river. When Abbas, the grandson of Asjot I, came to the throne and the Bagratid dynasty became more powerful, it moved its capital to Kars west of the Aras River to better protect the trade route from the Caucasus to the Black Sea and resist Byzantine aggression. Encroaching eastward. After Abbas's son Ashot III came to the throne, he moved the capital to Ani on the west bank of the Arras River. It never moved the capital again until the demise of the dynasty in 1045 AD.

;

;;

;

;Haystacks in Armenia;(Wang Zaitian./Photo);

;

;Civilized Transfer Station< /h3>;

;The Kingdom of Armenia was the first Christian country in the world. After the resurgence, the Bagratid Dynasty continued the status of the Armenian Apostolic Church as the state religion and consolidated the legitimacy of its regime by sending large amounts of donations to the church. As a result of this approach, the ancient capital Ani was once dotted with churches and was known as the "City of One Thousand and One Churches".

;

;Another title of Ani is the "City of Forty Gates", which refers to its vast area and abundant business travel. But today there is only one north gate left in Ani. The later conquerors, the Seljuqs, built an outer wall around the north gate to form a corridor-like urn city, which improved the defensive function of the city gate. This only remaining city gate was named after the Seljuk Sultan Arslan who captured Ani in 1064, and was called the Gate of Arslan.

;

;How to defend the city of Ani with only one gate left? Out of the way. The terrain of Ani is very similar to the Jiaohe Ancient City in Turpan. It is located on a platform formed by three deep rivers. There are almost dry deep valleys to the east and west, and the steep Alas Valley to the south, forming a natural moat. Only the north has a road leading to the outside world. In the era of cold weapons, it was really a great pass that was easy to defend but difficult to attack.

;

;Ani is located at the crossroads of the Caucasus Mountains to the south, Persia to the west, Mesopotamia to the north and Asia Minor to the east. Its location is very important. In addition, it is adjacent to the Arras Valley and has abundant water resources. The trade routes in the Volga River Basin that crossed the Caucasus Mountains merged into the junction of the Silk Road, thus witnessing the rise and fall of ancient civilizations one after another.

;

;In addition to the Armenians, the Byzantines attacked Ani three times in history until they captured the city in 1045. Afterwards, Ani became an important eastern town in the Byzantine Empire equivalent to the capital Constantinople. , there were 100,000 residents living on this platform in its heyday, marking the Caucasus entered its commercial heyday under Byzantine rule. Unfortunately, the good times did not last long. With the decline of Arab power in Central Asia, the Seljuqs rose rapidly and occupied the ecological niche of the Arabs. They then defeated the bloated Byzantine army in the west and captured Ani in 1064, starting from there. Asia Minor turned the Caucasus into its own backyard.

;

;After the Seljuks left, Ani was successively occupied by the Georgians and Kurds. It was not until 1239 that the short-lived Mongols conquered Ani. This was the last time the city was captured—— A major earthquake 80 years later destroyed most of the buildings in the city, forming the ruins we see today. In addition, the Ottoman Turkish Empire straddled the east coast of the Mediterranean and the Balkan Peninsula, cutting off the Silk Road between Western Europe and East Asia. As a result, Ani's status as a trade center no longer existed and it declined rapidly.

;

;After the Ottoman Turkish Empire gradually declined in the 19th century, Ani and Kars fell into the hands of Tsarist Russia for a time, and only returned to Turkish hands after World War I. During the Cold War era, this was the border between the Warsaw Pact and NATO in Asia. Once the Soviet armored forces broke out of the Caucasus mountains, they would flood into the Anatolian Plateau. This has become Turkey's nightmare for many years. Both Turkey and the Soviet Union stationed heavy troops along the Arras Valley, and Ani was under military control for 40 years as an important border defense area. It was not until the collapse of the Soviet Union, Armenia's independence, and the disappearance of the military threat faced by Turkey that control policies were relaxed. But at first, tourists still needed to apply in advance before entering the ancient city of Ani, just like my country's border permit system, which was canceled after Erdogan came to power in 2003.

;

;;

;

;The ruins of the ancient city of Ani can overlook the rocky village on the opposite cliff, giving you a sense of Cappadocia. ;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;The city of one thousand and one churches

;

;The ancient city of Ani has been abandoned for several years For centuries, the landform has basically returned to its original appearance in ancient times. Only a dozen of the most magnificent and solid ancient buildings remain, which have withstood the test of time and natural disasters and stand quietly in the grass, silently displaying the civilizations left by different eras. imprint.

;

;St. Gregory was the founder of the Armenian Apostolic Church. He was imprisoned in a dungeon for 13 years by King Tiridates III of Armenia. Finally, he used miracles to convert the king and established the world's first Christian country. , so he is regarded as the patron saint by the Armenians. There are three churches named after St. Gregory in Ani. Among them, the one near the north gate is also called Abughamrents. It was built in 994 AD and has a conical roof and 12 walls on the facade. The niche is a typical Armenian architectural style and is very eye-catching on the withered yellow grassland. From here, you can overlook the rocky villages on the opposite cliff to the west, giving you a sense of Cappadocia.

;

;Another Armenian-style church is the Church of Redeemer. Although it is small in size, it is the most fascinating place in the city of Ani. This church was built between 1034 and 1036 AD to store the "True Cross" gifted by the Byzantine Empire, which is the legendary fragment of the cross that crucified Jesus Christ. The "True Cross" is like the Buddha's relic in Buddhism. It is not uncommon in the Christian world, and its authenticity is doubtful. The Church of Our Savior is fascinating because it has stood for more than 900 years and has survived wars and earthquakes. It is the only well-preserved ancient building in the entire ancient city of Ani. However, it was accidentally struck by lightning in 1957, leaving only half of the outer wall. Standing among the rubble with the vault, it looks like a warrior whose skin has been eroded but whose skeleton is erect, showing a unique desolate beauty in this thousand-year-old ruins.

;

;;

;

;Church of the Saviour;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;The most magnificent church in Ani is The Byzantine-style Ani Cathedral was designed by Trdat Mendet, the master architect who presided over the reconstruction of Hagia Sophia in Constantinople. Construction started in 987 AD and took 24 years to complete. This cathedral looks inconspicuous from a distance, like a magnificent mansion. When you walk into the church and take a closer look, you will find that it combines grandeur and exquisiteness: the grandeur is reflected in the tall red and black basalt columns inside - Byzantine style architecture. The main purpose of the architect is to use height to create a gap in a limited space, so that believers will feel awe; the exquisiteness is reflected in the meticulous carvings everywhere in the church, making believers sigh for the perfection of heaven and earth.

;

;Like Hagia Sophia, Ani Cathedral was converted into a mosque by the Seljuq conquerors who believed in Islam, named "Victory". After the Seljuks left, the Georgians and Armenians turned it back into a church, and after the Turks came, they turned it into a mosque again... After several rounds of sawing, the vault, which was the soul of the Byzantine church building, collapsed, and so No one cares about this cathedral anymore, and it stands alone overlooking the rushing Aras river below.

;

;;

;

;Cathedral;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;Another St. Gregory the Great in the west of the city The church was also built by Trdat Mendet, which makes me suspect that this is a character similar to the water conservancy engineer Zheng Guo at the end of the Warring States Period, who was sent by the Byzantine Empire to consume the national power of the Bagratid Dynasty. Its vault design is exactly the same as that of Hagia Sophia. Unfortunately, it collapsed not long after it was built, and now only a huge circular base and a pile of rubble remain. On its northeast side is a Georgian church, and on its east side is the Zoroastrian temple left by the Persians, which is the oldest architectural remains in the entire city of Ani.

;

;The third St. Gregory the Great Church in Ani was built in 1215 and was funded by a wealthy Armenian businessman. It witnessed the final glory of Ani. Just over twenty years later, the Mongols came over, slaughtered all the civilians, and turned the castle into a camp. Later Turks called this church Resimli Kilise, which means mural church. It is hidden halfway up the valley and is not easily visible from the mesa. There are long Armenian inscriptions on the outer wall of the church, and a large number of early Christian murals are preserved inside. The lines are elegant and smooth, and there is no dullness in such religious propaganda paintings of the same period.

;

;

;Fresco church;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;;

;

;Mural church preservation The murals ;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;Finally, let’s talk about the marks left by the Seljuks. The first is the Church of Holy Apostles built by the Armenians. The Seljuks actually opened a new arch in it, which is transparent from north to south, and turned into a large car shop for resting caravans. But because of this, the church escaped the war and fire, and its internal structure and decoration are well preserved. Its rib arches, carvings and mosaics can still be clearly seen today.

;

;There is a red-brown building on the cliff south of the ancient city. From a distance, it looks like a rectangular factory building with a large chimney. The architectural style is very different from the surrounding Armenian or Byzantine churches, but the color scheme is similar. This is actually the first mosque in Turkish history. It was built by the Seljuqs in 1072. It adopts the Armenian red and black color scheme. The "big chimney" is a minaret, but the top of the tower has collapsed. . The mosque overlooks the Arras Valley. There is the Monastery of Our Lady and the Broken Bridge at the bottom of the valley. Armenia is on the other side of the river. Since Turkey and Armenia are feuding countries, they have not yet established diplomatic relations, and the borders between the two countries are naturally closed to each other.

;

;;

;

;Mosque;(Wang Zaitian/Photo);

;

;The ancient city of Ani was listed as a A world cultural heritage, it is not only a witness to Armenia’s long civilization, but also a shining pearl on the Silk Road. Austrian art historian Josef Strzygowski once commented on Ani: Only the genius who built Hagia Sophia (Byzantium) and St. Peter's Basilica (Rome) can truly understand the importance of the Armenian pioneers.

;

;Unfortunately, blocked by ethnic hatred and geopolitics, Armenians are only separated from this thousand-year-old capital by a river, but they cannot visit it. Coincidentally, Mount Ararat, the spiritual totem of Armenian civilization, has also been assigned to Turkey. Armenians can only look up from outside the border at the foot of this perfect cone-shaped volcano. Although they are close at hand, they cannot take a step closer.

;

;Ani and Ararat are the cultural roots of the Armenian nation that are elusive!
